text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif declared that his party would undo the controversial parts of the Eight Amendment, including the power of the president to dissolve the assemblies, in order to restore democracy.
- The National Assembly (Parliament) adopted a finance bill that gave effect to the proposals contained in the recently announced economic reforms package.
- Pakistan and India ended four days of talks aimed at reducing tension and agreed to meet again in Islamabad.

- The Human Rights Commission of Pakistan made public its seventh annual report, noting the lack of any improvement in human rights situation in the country since the publication of its first report in 1990.
- Farmers and food department officials hope that Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will increase the wheat support price.
- Pakistan and Japan have signed the 31st yen package loan agreement worth $241 million for three major development projects.

- The government has decided to privatise state-run Pakistan State Oil, Oil and Gas Development Corporation, Sui Southern Gas Co and Sui Northern Gas Pipelines Ltd on priority basis which would yield at least 81 billion rupees, sources said.
- The World Bank has offered full support to the government for successful implementation of structural reforms announced last week.
